revision.text:
{{Infobox person | image = Mike Vogel SDCC 2014 (cropped).jpg | caption = Vogel at the [[San Diego Comic-Con International|San Diego Comic-Con]] in July 2014 | birth_name = Michael James Vogel | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1979|07|17}} | birth_place = [[Abington Township, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Abington Township, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | residence = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. | occupation = Actor, model | years_active = 2001–present | spouse = {{marriage|Courtney Vogel|2003}} | children = 3 | website = {{URL|http://mike-vogel.com/}} }} '''Michael James Vogel''' (born July 17, 1979){{cite web| title=Mike Vogel.com| work=Fun Facts| url=http://mike-vogel.com/?page_id=84| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110908015106/http://mike-vogel.com/?page_id=84| archivedate=2011-09-08| df=}} is an American actor and former model. Vogel began acting in 2001, and has since appeared in several films and series, including ''[[The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (2003 film)|The Texas Chainsaw Massacre]]'', ''[[The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (film)|The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants]]'', ''[[Grind (2003 film)|Grind]]'', ''[[Poseidon (film)|Poseidon]]'', ''[[Blue Valentine (film)|Blue Valentine]]'', ''[[The Help (film)|The Help]]'', ''[[Bates Motel (TV series)|Bates Motel]]'', ''[[Cloverfield]]'', ''[[Under the Dome (TV series)|Under the Dome]]'' and ''[[The Case for Christ]]''. As of autumn 2017, he now plays the male lead in the new [[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]] military drama series ''[[The Brave (TV series)|The Brave]]'' for the 2017–18 season. ==Early life== Vogel was born in [[Abington Township, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Abington Township, Pennsylvania]], a suburb of [[Philadelphia]], to Kathy and Jim Vogel,http://warminster.patch.com/groups/arts-and-entertainment/p/warminster-parents-watch-sons-star-shine-under-the-dome and was raised in [[Warminster Township, Pennsylvania]]. Both of his grandfathers fought in [[World War II]]; one was a tank commander who fought in the [[Battle of the Bulge]], and the other was a [[Seabee]] in the [[United States Navy|Navy]].{{cite web |last=Barker |first=Lynn |url=http://www.teenhollywood.com/2006/05/10/mike-vogel-takes-us-underwater |title=Mike Vogel Takes Us Underwater |publisher=TeenHollywood |date=May 10, 2006 |accessdate=September 13, 2013}} Vogel has two younger siblings: a brother, Daniel Aaron, and a sister, Kristin. He attended [[William Tennent High School]], the same [[high school]] as [[Sprint Nextel|Sprint]] spokesman Brian Baker and boxer [[Kermit Cintron]], where Vogel was on the Freshman wrestling team. He also attended [[Cairn University]] in Langhorne, Pennsylvania in 1998. During the early 2000s, he frequently traveled to [[New York City]] in order to audition for acting roles and modeling slots. ==Career== [[File:Mike Vogel - Poseidon Premiere.jpg|thumb|left|Vogel at the [[London]] premiere of ''[[Poseidon (film)|Poseidon]]'' in May 2006]] Vogel began modeling for [[Levi's]], and was subsequently cast in the television series ''[[Grounded for Life]]'' appearing in a recurring role between 2001 and 2004. His first film role was in the [[skateboard]]ing-themed ''[[Grind (2003 film)|Grind]]'', which was released on August 15, 2003. The film's co-stars included [[Adam Brody]] and [[Jennifer Morrison]]. Vogel's next role was in the [[made-for-television]] remake of ''[[Wuthering Heights (2003 film)|Wuthering Heights]]'', which premiered on [[MTV]] a month after ''Grind'''s release, in September 2003. In the film, Vogel played Heath opposite [[Erika Christensen]]'s Kate. Vogel's last 2003 role was in the remake of ''The Texas Chainsaw Massacre'', which was released in October to high box office performance. In 2005, after ''[[Grounded for Life]]'' was canceled, Vogel appeared in four film roles. First, he played Eric Richman, the romantic interest of [[Blake Lively]]'s character in ''[[The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (film)|The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants]]'', which had a June release. His next role was the lead in the low-budget film, ''[[Supercross (film)|Supercross]]'', which was theatrically released in August. Vogel filmed his role in ''[[Havoc (2005 film)|Havoc]]'', a dark, R-rated drama also starring [[Anne Hathaway]], in 2003, but the film was not released until November 2005, when it bypassed theaters and was released directly-to-video. Vogel's final 2005 role was in ''[[Rumor Has It...]]'', starring [[Jennifer Aniston]], in which he had a supporting role as the son of [[Kevin Costner]]'s character. [[File:Mike Vogel Gitmo.jpg|thumb|right|Vogel at [[Joint Task Force Guantanamo]] in June 2008]] Vogel's first 2006 role was in the [[disaster film]] ''[[Poseidon (film)|Poseidon]]'', a remake of the 1972 film ''[[The Poseidon Adventure (1972 film)|The Poseidon Adventure]]''; he plays the fiancé of [[Emmy Rossum]]'s character. The film, which had a budget of $160m, opened on May 12 and grossed $181,674,817 at the international box office. Vogel was originally offered the role of [[Archangel (comics)|Angel]] in ''[[X-Men: The Last Stand]]'', but backed out to appear in ''Poseidon''.{{cite web|title=Winnipeg Sun |work=MARRIED WITH CAPITAL M |url=http://winnipegsun.com/SundayFocus/2006/05/14/1579020-sun.html |accessdate=May 14, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060527040322/http://winnipegsun.com/SundayFocus/2006/05/14/1579020-sun.html |archivedate=May 27, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The same year, he appeared in ''[[Caffeine (film)|Caffeine]]'', a [[romantic comedy]] and signed to appear in a horror movie called ''[[Open Graves]]'', shot in [[Spain]]. In 2007, Vogel appeared in the film ''[[The Deaths of Ian Stone]]'', part of the [[horror film|horror]] [[film festival]] [[8 Films to Die For]]. In 2009, Vogel starred in the [[neo-noir]] film ''[[Across the Hall (2009 film)|Across the Hall]]'' and the horror film ''[[Open Graves]]''. He was part of the 2010 romantic comedy film ''[[She's Out of My League]]'', ''[[Blue Valentine (film)|Blue Valentine]]'', TV series ''[[Miami Medical]]'' and ''[[Heaven's Rain]]''. Vogel was part of the 2011 comedy film ''[[What's Your Number?]]'' and plays Johnny Foote in the film adaption ''[[The Help (film)|The Help]]''. He most recently played Dean on the short-lived [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] drama ''[[Pan Am (TV series)|Pan Am]]'' (based on the defunct [[Pan American World Airways|airline of the same name]]). In 2013, he participated in Howard Goldberg's comedy [[Jake Squared]] where he plays against among others, [[Elias Koteas]], [[Virginia Madsen]] and [[Jane Seymour (actress)|Jane Seymour]]. He also appeared in ''[[McCanick]]'', and the first six episodes of ''[[Bates Motel (TV series)|Bates Motel]]'', [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]]'s contemporary prequel series to the 1959 novel ''[[Psycho (novel)|Psycho]]''. [[BuddyTV]] ranked him #96 on its list of "TV's Sexiest Men of 2011".{{cite web|url=http://www.buddytv.com/slideshows/white-collar/tvs-100-sexiest-men-of-2011-29104.aspx|title=TV's 100 Sexiest Men of 2011|publisher=[[BuddyTV]]|accessdate=January 13, 2012}} Vogel also starred as Dale "Barbie" Barbara on the [[CBS]] science fiction drama series ''[[Under the Dome (TV series)|Under the Dome]]'', based on the [[Under the Dome (novel)|novel of the same name]] by [[Stephen King]]. The show aired as a summer series on CBS and it lasted for three seasons on the network, ending in September 2015. In 2014, he received a role in The Hallmark Hall Of Fame's romantic TV movie [[In My Dreams (film)|In My Dreams]], in which he plays against among others, [[Katharine McPhee]] and [[JoBeth Williams]]. In the same year played in the drama thriller ''[[The Boy (2015 film)|The Boy]]'', which tells the story of a 9 year old [[Sociopathy|Sociopath]], which was played by [[Jared Breeze]].{{cite web|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/indie/3334640/sxsw-15-meet-sociopath-known-boy/|title=The Boy|publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|accessdate=January 13, 2012}} In 2015, Vogel starred in the miniseries ''[[Childhood's End]]'', based on the novel ''Childhood's End'', written by [[Arthur C. Clarke]]. In 2017, Vogel starred in the film adaptation of [[Lee Strobel]]'s ''[[The Case for Christ]]'' portraying the author and teaming up again with co-star [[Erika Christensen]]. On September 25, 2017, [[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]] debuted ''[[The Brave (TV series)|The Brave]]'', for the 2017-18 season. A small team of hardcore military-intelligence agents from varied branches of the service is selected for special, difficult missions. Among them is male lead Vogel's character, Capt. Adam Dalton, the team's communications director and a former [[Delta Force]] operative, who answers to the character played by series lead [[Anne Heche]].{{cite web |last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |date=February 15, 2017 |title=Mike Vogel To Topline 'For God And Country' NBC Military Drama Pilot |url=http://deadline.com/2017/02/mike-vogel-star-for-god-and-country-nbc-military-drama-pilot-1201913259/ |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=February 15, 2017}} ==Personal life== Vogel married Courtney, a former model, in January 2003, with whom he has three children: Cassy Renee Vogel, born 2007; Charlee B. Vogel, born 2009; and Gabriel James Vogel, born 2013. The family resides in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] and has 1 pug, Olivia, and 2 horses, Mr. Benjamin Buttons and Mr. Ghost.http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2013/08/m-under-the-domes-mike-vogel-actors-are-the-dumbest-group-of-individuals-essentially-out-there.html{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" ! Year ! Title ! Adam Dalton | Main cast |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{Official website|http://mike-vogel.com/}} * {{IMDb name|1036181}} {{Broadcast Film Critics Association Award for Best Cast}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vogel, Mike}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:21st-century American male actors]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:Male models from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:American people of German descent]] [[Category:Aviators from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Contestants on American game shows]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Male actors from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture Screen Actors Guild Award winners]] [[Category:People from Abington Township, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:People from Warminster, Pennsylvania]]
